intro: Didiscus anisocarpus, commonly known as the unequal-carpel didiscus, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Malvaceae. It is characterized by its unique floral structure, featuring a distinctive calyx that is often lobed and showy. The plant produces capsules as its fruit, with the carpels of varying sizes, giving it the specific epithet "anisocarpus." It is native to regions of Southeast Asia, including parts of India and Indonesia. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it is not widely known outside of botanical circles.
